resources.string: Do you want to start a new game? Your other game will be lost.
You have a paused game with this mode. This game will be lost when deleting this mode. Are you still sure you want to delete this mode?
Minesweeper is about finding all mines on a grid, without clicking directly on a mine. In this tutorial, we explain you how to play the game.\n\nSwipe left to continue.
Each grid contains a specific amount of mines. It\'s your task to flag all the mines in a grid.
When you press a cell, an area with numbers appears. Each cell shows the amount of mines in the adjacent 8 cells.
Mines should be flagged with a flag. When all mines are flagged, or all not-mines are revealed, you win the game.

The circular button in the bottom of the screen switches between modes. Red is reveal mode and green is flag mode.

In reveal mode, you can reveal unrevealed cells. You will lose when you press a mine. Long pressing in this mode will place a flag instead.

In flag mode, you can place flags on unrevealed cells. Long pressing in this mode will place a soft mark (question mark).

When a number sees his amount of adjacent flags, it can be clicked to reveal surrounding cells. This can be done in reveal and in flag mode. Beware, since mines could still be revealed when a flag is placed wrongly.
The game ends when you either win or lose. You lose when you reveal a mine. You win the game by either flagging all mines, or by revealing all cells without a mine, leaving only all mines unrevealed.
Try it yourself. In the beginning it will be hard to understand, but after some trying you would be able to solve one.
Uses a dark user interface, instead of the light one. Changing this will restart the app.
Determines the place of the mode switch button in the game.
Sets the size of the game cells.
Sets the corner radius of the game and the unrevealed cells.
Enables the checkerboard grid on the game board.
Size of a particular part that updates when a cell has changed there. Using higher values may drop performance but saves RAM usage.
Mark the revealed mine on lose
When to show a dialog after the game has ended.
Show flags inferred from surrounding numbers.
Specifies under which condition a game is won.
All not-mines are revealed or all mines are flagged
What to do on long pressing a cell in each mode (\"Reveal Mode - Flag Mode\").
What should happen to surrounding cell if a number is being tapped.
Prevent your device from automatically locking the screen during a game.
Mark numbers with too many flags
Prevent too much flags around a number
Prevent too much flags in total
When enabled, numbers that have inferred flags could be tapped to place all flags.
Mark numbers that can be completed
Determines how mines are generated after the first tap.
Random, but any tapped mine is moved
Amount of closed neighbors is this number
This number has too many flags
Only options for this number all complete another number
Flag next to an empty cell
No hint available: you\'ll probably need to guess

The original Minesweeper game for Android, but with a twist. This app is styled with the original Material design, and is equipped with a lot of settings to make your experience the best. And for the beginners, it is equipped with a tutorial and of coarse, live hints. And what\'s even better, it\'s completely free and open source, without ads, and it will always be.

Hello, I\'m a young, Dutch software developer from Drenthe. I started making this app because there was really no Minesweeper app on Google Play that is 1) free, 2) ad-free, 3) Material design based and 4) open source. Later, my teacher in Informatics told me that he would give me a grade based on my work, instead of letting me make a test that\'s too easy for me. The result: this app. And therefore I want to give a great \"thank you\" to:
Android Studio, for being the best Android IDE ever.
Inkscape, wherein I made the Icons that Google didn\'t make.
Material Color Tool, for letting me easily select the colors for the Material design.
Google, for making the Material design, and the beautiful icons.
My family, for testing the app and for helping me.
Github, for hosting (and backing up) my code.
Android, for being the best OS ever.
Everyone out there on StackOverflow, for having and solving all my problems before I had them.
Luckytoilet, for the Minesweeper solving algorithm, which I used to show live hints wherever possible.
My best friend, for being just a best friend.
All other people on the internet who posted articles that helped me solving problems.
And you, for downloading and using my app.
My teacher in Informatics, for grading my project.
